title: SAs Google Maps Renames Neighborhoods, Residents Fume
abstract: Google’s digital maps have become the world’s default atlas and the arbiter of what neighborhoods are called, even when many residents disagree.

title: SPeloton’s New Infusion Made It a $4 Billion Company in 6 Years
abstract: The fitness company selling stationary bikes and subscriptions to live classes once confused investors. Now, after new financing of $550 million, it’s the toast of Silicon Valley.

title: Amazon Removes Products Featuring Nazi Symbols
abstract: The retailer said it would not let third-party merchants sell goods with Nazi and white nationalist symbols on its platform, amid pressure from nonprofits and lawmakers.

title: The Week in Tech: SoftBank Strikes Again
abstract: Every SoftBank investment can make waves, just like the $240 million one in Brandless that it made this week.

title: ‘The Beginning of a Wave’: A.I. Tiptoes Into the Workplace
abstract: Artificial intelligence software is making its presence felt in subtle ways, in an unglamorous place: the back office.

title: Disney’s Streaming Service Starts to Come Into Focus
abstract: Ricky Strauss, a successful marketer, has been given oversight of original films and TV shows for Disney’s coming streaming service. Does he have what it takes?

title: Cities’ Offers for Amazon Base Are Secrets Even to Many City Leaders
abstract: As Amazon continues its search for its second headquarters, some city officials wonder what was offered and how much it will cost taxpayers.

title: The Future Is ... Personal Ads?
abstract: A queer online dating community has formed around an old-school format for hookups.

title: The Basic Ingredients for Your Podcast Recipe
abstract: Making your own audio show can be fun and relatively inexpensive, but you should have a plan and get the right gear before you hit the Record button.

title: Times Stands By Editorial Board Member After Outcry Over Old Tweets
abstract: The New York Times said Sarah Jeong, who was hired on Wednesday, would keep her job. Tweets she wrote from 2013 to early 2015 that were critical of white people resurfaced after her hiring.

title: Apple Is Worth $1,000,000,000,000. Two Decades Ago, It Was Almost Bankrupt.
abstract: Steve Jobs said Apple was 90 days from bankruptcy in 1997. Now it is the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1 trillion.

title: Scrub Your Android Tablet Before Handing It Down
abstract: Before giving your device to a family member or selling it to someone else, be sure to erase all the content and remove your accounts.

title: How Fake Influence Campaigns on Facebook Lured Real People
abstract: Activists became entangled with fake accounts and pages on Facebook, leading to significant consequences for them as the company tried to clamp down.

title: Facebook Grapples With a Maturing Adversary in Election Meddling
abstract: The influence campaign revealed on Tuesday is adapting and evolving to better disguise itself, which limits the social network’s approach to stopping it.

title: Tesla Reports Another Big Loss, but Sees Only Profit Ahead
abstract: Elon Musk, the chief executive, said the electric-car maker was about to turn a corner with output of its mass-market Model 3, buoying company shares.

title: Facebook’s Security Chief to Depart for Stanford University
abstract: Alex Stamos, Facebook’s chief security officer, is joining Stanford to teach and to examine the role of security and technology in society.

title: Autoplay Videos Are Not Going Away. Here’s How to Fight Them.
abstract: Videos that start without your consent are prominent across the web. Our tech columnist explains how the industry got here and what we can do.

title: What Is QAnon: Explaining the Internet Conspiracy Theory That Showed Up at a Trump Rally
abstract: Do you remember Pizzagate? It’s a little like that: a web of baseless conspiracy theories. And its supporters were highly visible at an event for the president in Florida.

title: Google, Seeking a Return to China, Is Said to Be Building a Censored Search Engine
abstract: Google withdrew from China in 2010 to protest the country’s censorship. Now the internet giant is working on a search engine that complies with Chinese censorship rules.

title: Gaza and Google Translate: Covering the Conflict When You Don’t Speak the Language
abstract: David M. Halbfinger, The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief, found Google Translate useful in Israeli and Palestinian territory, but Waze sometimes reaches a dead end.

title: Campaigns Enter Texting Era With a Plea: Will U Vote 4 Me?
abstract: Welcome to the age of the political mass-text. Candidates in this year’s midterm elections are adding a new, hard-to-ignore tool to their arsenal.

title: Find Recently Lost Files on Your Mac
abstract: Can’t locate that file you were working in a few days ago and can’t remember what you called it? Here are some places to look.

title: Data Breaches Keep Happening. So Why Don’t You Do Something?
abstract: News about leaks of personal information can lead consumers to believe that’s the new normal, but experts caution against such “breach fatigue.”

title: Stumbles? What Stumbles? Big Tech Is as Strong as Ever
abstract: Facebook’s earnings report sent tech stocks cratering. But don’t let that fool you: Apple, Google, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are still on their way to dominating the future.

title: Apple Could Soon Be Worth $1 Trillion as Profits Pour In
abstract: Profits rose by nearly a third in the latest quarter, Apple said, news that could soon make the tech giant the first public company worth more than $1 trillion.

title: San Francisco Officials to Tech Workers: Buy Your Lunch
abstract: A proposed ordinance would ban employee cafeterias in new construction, encouraging tech workers to leave the office to buy their meals.

title: Facebook Identifies an Active Political Influence Campaign Using Fake Accounts
abstract: A coordinated effort, involving 32 pages and fake accounts, included amplifying division around white supremacy and the #AbolishICE movement, the social network said.

title: How to Stop Facebook From Bringing Up Bad Memories
abstract: Before the social network makes automatic videos of your photos, tell it the names of the people you don’t wish to see in the clips.

title: The Fight for the One-Piece Swimsuit Emoji
abstract: Why is the only bathing suit available in the emoji lexicon a polka-dot bikini? Two women have finally proposed an alternative. Not everyone is convinced.

title: How to Get a Weekly View in Apple’s Calendar
abstract: A few iOS apps show different screens when you rotate a phone to a horizontal position.

title: The Hidden Language of Hands Videos
abstract: In the age of the selfie, we spend a lot of time showing off our faces. But lately a different body part is vying for attention. (Well: two.) What are our hands trying to tell us? Episode 3 of our video series.

title: Welcome Our New Fembot Overlords
abstract: From digital helpmates like Siri to computer-generated Instagram models like Lil Miquela, feminized tech is all around us. Are actual human women starting to look a little bit unreal? Episode 2 of our video series.

title: Dogs Took Over the Internet. Our Souls Are at Stake.
abstract: Dogs are order. Cats are chaos. Dogs are loyal and compliant. Cats are … not. Why has the internet suddenly switched its allegiance? Episode 1 of our video series.
